page.title: 05NATIONAL TRUST UPKEEP
page.content: In 1977 the reservoir on Blackdown was enlarged. Bridleways and footpaths have to be kept clear of over-hanging branches and open grassland is kept mown. Ditches have to be cleared and bracken destroyed to allow heather to grow. Rhododendrons were cleared in 1981. Birches and other young trees are thinned and the lower branches removed from timber trees by brashing The Trust sells timber from the pines and hardwoods which regenerate naturally. In 1979 Scots Pines on Blackdown were thinned; Conservation Volunteers have cleared areas of young birch and Pines. There are plantations of European and Hybrid Larch and Hemlock on Marley. In 1980, one thousand Norway Sruce were planted at Boarden Door Bottom and 100 Scots pines were felled.
